title: Udayan Mantri and His Sons: A Detailed Timeline
subtitle: I.4 JAB Manual 5th edition

storyContent.tagHTML: Original Story: Udayan Mantri and His Sons
I.4.1. Udayan Mantri (Minister)

The Solanki dynasty was a golden period for Gujarat, especially during King Kumärpäl's reign. Much of this success was thanks to his chancellors (Mantri), many of whom were Jains. The most important was Udayan Mantri and his sons, Ämbad and Bähad.

Udayan started as a simple merchant in the village of Vägharä, near Jälore, Rajasthan. Life was hard, so his wife, Suhädevi, suggested they move somewhere with more opportunities. They decided on Gujarat, where King Siddharäj was ruling.

King Siddharäj had just built a new town called Karnävati (Amdäväd). Udayan and his wife moved there, and with nowhere to go, they visited the local Jain temple. There, they met a kind lady named Lachchhi. She took them in and even gave them an old house to live in.

Luck was on Udayan's side! While fixing up the house, he found a hidden treasure. Being an honest man, he offered it to Lachchhi, but she said that since the house was his, the treasure was too. With this newfound wealth, Udayan's business grew, and he became the wealthiest man in Karnävati. He was even made the city's first citizen.
Later, in 1120 A.D., Udayan became the governor of Khambhät, a major seaport. During his time as governor, he did two very important things:

• At the suggestion of queen mother Minaldevi, he abolished a pilgrim tax.
  • He helped a great teacher, Devchandra-suri, initiate a five-year-old boy named Chängdev, who would grow up to be the famous Jain Ächärya Shri Hemchandra.

Udayan was very loyal. When King Kumärpäl was hiding from King Siddharäj, Udayan, advised by Shri Hemchandra Ächärya, bravely hid the future king in his basement. When Kumärpäl became king, he made Udayan his trusted advisor in the capital city, Pätan.

Udayan never forgot his faith. He built many Jain temples in Karnävati, Dholka, and Khambhät. Later in life, while on a mission to stop a bandit named Sumvar, he visited the holy Shatrunjay hill. While praying in the wooden temple there, he saw a mouse with a lit wick, and realized the temple could easily burn down. Right then, he vowed to build a new, strong temple.
Udayan won his battle but was badly hurt. On his deathbed, he told his sons about his vow. They promised to fulfill it, and he died peacefully.
I.4.2. Ämbad and Bähad
Udayan had four sons: Ämbad, Bähad, Chähad, and Sollak.

Ämbad was a brave warrior and became chancellor for King Kumärpäl. He built and renovated many religious sites. When the next king, Ajaypäl, tried to undo all of Kumärpäl's good work, Ämbad stood up to him and died fighting for what he believed in.
Bähad was a great politician. He served King Kumärpäl as his trusted right-hand man and renovated the famous Somnäth temple.
Most importantly, to honor his father's pledge, Bähad built the grand temple on Shatrunjay hill. It was first finished in 1155 A.D., but high winds damaged it. So, he rebuilt it to be even stronger.
There is a wonderful story about this project. A poor ghee-seller named Bhim wanted to donate, but he only had one coin. Bähad noticed his desire and encouraged him to give what he could.

Bähad not only accepted the single coin, but he also wrote Bhim's name at the very top of the donor list. When asked why, Bähad explained, "Other donors gave a part of their wealth. Bhim gave his *entire* wealth."
That day, when Bhim went home, he found a buried treasure of gold coins! Believing it was a reward for his good deed, he donated all of it to the temple project.
The beautiful temple was finally completed in 1157 A.D. in a grand ceremony with Shri Hemchandra Ächärya.
Moral of the Story

The story of Udayan shows us the power of being hardworking, religious, and humble. He raised brave and good sons. The story of Bhim teaches us that it's not how much you give, but the spirit in which you give it, that truly matters.

events.title: Merchant in Vägharä
events.description: Udayan was a simple merchant in Vägharä, near Jälore, Rajasthan, struggling financially.

events.title: Move to Karnävati
events.description: At his wife Suhädevi's suggestion, Udayan decided to migrate to Karnävati (Amdäväd), a fast-growing city in Gujarat under King Siddharäj, for better economic prospects.

events.title: Meets Lachchhi
events.description: Upon arriving in Karnävati, Udayan and Suhädevi went to the local Jain temple where they met Lachchhi, a compassionate religious lady.

events.title: Hosted by Lachchhi
events.description: Lachchhi hosted the couple for a few days and then gave them an old house for shelter.

events.title: Discovery of Treasure
events.description: While renovating the old house after starting a small business, Udayan discovered a hidden treasure. He honestly offered it to Lachchhi, but she declined.

events.title: Becomes Wealthiest Man
events.description: With the found treasure, Udayan started a large-scale business and became the wealthiest man in Karnävati.

events.title: Appointed First Citizen
events.description: Udayan was recognized by the state and appointed as the first citizen of Karnävati, rendering valuable service to the townspeople.

events.title: Appointed Governor
events.description: Udayan was appointed governor of Khambhät, a lucrative seaport, in 1120 A.D., holding the position for a long period.

events.title: Pilgrim Tax Abolished
events.description: At the suggestion of Queen Mother Minaldevi, Udayan abolished the pilgrim tax of Bholad.

events.title: Chängdev Initiated
events.description: Udayan helped Devchandra-suri initiate Chängdev (who later became the great Jain Ächärya Shri Hemchandra) at a young age.

events.title: Shelters King Kumärpäl
events.description: Advised by Hemchandra Ächärya, Udayan hid King Kumärpäl in his basement while Kumärpäl was hiding from King Siddharäj.

events.title: Becomes Trusted Advisor
events.description: After King Siddharäj died and Kumärpäl became king, Udayan was kept as governor of Khambhät and later brought to Pätan as King Kumärpäl's trusted advisor.

events.title: Promotes Jainism & Builds Temples
events.description: Udayan used his wealth and position to promote Jainism, constructing several temples including Udayanvihär in Karnävati, Udävasahi in Dholka, and one in Khambhät.

events.title: Subdues Bandit Sumvar
events.description: King Kumärpäl sent Udayan to subdue Sumvar, a notorious bandit in the Saurashtra region.

events.title: Pilgrimage to Shatrunjay
events.description: During his mission, Udayan went on a pilgrimage to Shatrunjay hill in Pälitänä.

events.title: Statue Erected
events.description: To commemorate his pilgrimage, Udayan's statue was erected on a camel's back in a small temple on the way to the main complex on the hill.

events.title: Vows New Temple
events.description: While worshipping in a wooden temple on Shatrunjay, Udayan observed a mouse almost setting it on fire, prompting him to vow to construct a new, safer temple there.

events.title: Deathbed Vow
events.description: After succeeding against Sumvar but being badly wounded, Udayan, on his deathbed, told his sons Ämbad and Bähad about his vow to reconstruct the Shatrunjay temple. They promised to fulfill it, and he died peacefully.

events.title: Four Sons of Udayan
events.description: Udayan had four sons: Ämbad, Bähad, Chähad, and Sollak.

events.title: Ämbad Becomes Chancellor
events.description: Ämbad, a poet and warrior, became the chancellor of King Kumärpäl.

events.title: Ämbad's Constructions
events.description: Ämbad constructed the western walkway (Gheti Ni Päg) on Shatrunjay hill, expanded Udävasahi of Dholka, and renovated Shakunikävihär at Bharuch.

events.title: Ämbad Resists King Ajaypäl & Dies
events.description: Ämbad pledged allegiance to Kumärpäl but resisted his successor, King Ajaypäl, dying in combat against Ajaypäl's troops.

events.title: Bähad's Career
events.description: Bähad (also known as Vähad), a politician and statesman, worked for King Siddharäj and became King Kumärpäl's trusted right-hand man.

events.title: Somnäth Temple Renovation
events.description: King Kumärpäl entrusted Bähad with the renovation of the Somnäth temple, which he carried out successfully.

events.title: Shatrunjay Temple Construction (Initial)
events.description: To honor his father's vow, Bähad undertook the construction of a grand temple on Shatrunjay. It was completed in 1155 A.D., but parts fell due to strong winds.

events.title: Bhim's Donation
events.description: Bähad noticed a poor man named Bhim who wished to donate his only coin. Bähad accepted it and put Bhim's name at the top of the donors' list, recognizing his full contribution.

events.title: Bhim Finds Treasure
events.description: After his donation, Bhim discovered a buried box of gold coins and valuables at home, which he also brought to Bähad as a contribution.

events.title: Shatrunjay Temple Reconstruction & Completion
events.description: Bähad arranged to reconstruct the fallen parts of the Shatrunjay temple to withstand high winds. The project was completed in 1157 A.D. at a cost of 29.7 million coins, with a grand opening ceremony led by Shri Hemchandra Ächärya.

charactersData.name: Udayan Mantri
charactersData.description: A simple merchant from Vägharä who rose to become the wealthiest man in Karnävati, then governor of Khambhät (1120 A.D.), and finally King Kumärpäl's trusted advisor. He was a devout Jain who promoted Jainism and vowed to rebuild the Shatrunjay temple.

charactersData.name: Suhädevi
charactersData.description: Udayan Mantri's wife, who suggested they move to Gujarat for better economic opportunities.

charactersData.name: King Siddharäj
charactersData.description: The ruler of Gujarat who built Karnävati (Amdäväd). Udayan worked for him and later hid King Kumärpäl from him.

charactersData.name: Lachchhi
charactersData.description: A compassionate religious lady in Karnävati who hosted Udayan and Suhädevi and provided them with an old house, declining the treasure Udayan found there.

charactersData.name: King Kumärpäl
charactersData.description: The king of Gujarat during whose reign prosperity peaked. He was sheltered by Udayan, who later became his trusted advisor. Udayan's sons Ämbad and Bähad also served him.

charactersData.name: Queen Mother Minaldevi
charactersData.description: The queen mother who suggested Udayan abolish the pilgrim tax of Bholad.

charactersData.name: Devchandra-suri
charactersData.description: A Jain guru who initiated Chängdev (later Hemchandra Ächärya) with Udayan's help.

charactersData.name: Shri Hemchandra Ächärya (Chängdev)
charactersData.description: A great Jain Ächärya who was initiated with Udayan's help. He advised Udayan to shelter King Kumärpäl and later officiated the opening ceremony of Bähad's temple.

charactersData.name: Sumvar
charactersData.description: A notorious bandit in the Saurashtra region whom Udayan Mantri was sent to subdue.

charactersData.name: Ämbad
charactersData.description: Udayan's son, a poet and bold warrior who became King Kumärpäl's chancellor. He constructed and renovated several structures but died fighting King Ajaypäl.

charactersData.name: Bähad (Vähad)
charactersData.description: Udayan's second son, a politician and statesman. He first worked for King Siddharäj, and under King Kumärpäl's regime became the king's trusted right-hand man. He completed the renovation of Somnäth temple and fulfilled his father's vow by constructing a grand temple on Shatrunjay hill.

charactersData.name: King Ajaypäl
charactersData.description: King Kumärpäl's successor, whom Ämbad resisted and died fighting against.

charactersData.name: Bhim
charactersData.description: A poor ghee seller who donated his single coin to Bähad's temple project and was placed at the top of the donor list for his full contribution. He later found treasure.

quizData.question: From which village did Udayan originally come?
What was the name of Udayan's wife?
What was the name of the new town King Siddharäj had built, which Udayan migrated to?
What was the name of the religious lady who provided Udayan and his wife shelter?
In what year was Udayan appointed governor of Khambhät?
What was the name of the queen mother who suggested abolishing the pilgrim tax of Bholad?
What was the name of the great Jain Ächärya whom Udayan helped initiate (originally named Chängdev)?
On which hill did Udayan vow to construct a new temple after observing a mouse incident?
Which of Udayan's sons was entrusted with the renovation of the Somnäth temple?
What was the name of the poor man who donated his entire wealth to the temple project and was placed at the top of the donor list?

graphicsData.title: A Fortunate Discovery
graphicsData.description: After being given shelter by the kind Lachchhi, Udayan discovers a hidden treasure, which sets him on a path to becoming a wealthy and influential citizen.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Udayan, looking astonished, unearths a pot of gold coins while renovating a simple house.

graphicsData.title: An Act of Loyalty
graphicsData.description: Advised by Shri Hemchandra Ächärya, Governor Udayan risks everything to hide the future King Kumärpäl from his enemies.
graphicsData.imageAlt: In a dark basement, Udayan offers food to a disguised King Kumärpäl.

graphicsData.title: The Vow at Shatrunjay
graphicsData.description: Seeing how easily the wooden temple on Shatrunjay hill could burn, Udayan makes a solemn vow to build a new, grander temple of stone.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Udayan looks on in alarm as a mouse with a lit wick scurries through a wooden temple.

graphicsData.title: A Single Coin's Worth
graphicsData.description: Udayan's son Bähad honors the poor man Bhim by placing his name at the top of the donor list for the new temple.
graphicsData.dialogue: Bähad: "He has contributed his entire wealth."
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bähad kindly accepts a single coin from a poor but earnest ghee-seller named Bhim.

graphicsData.title: A Principled Stand
graphicsData.description: Udayan's other son, the warrior Ämbad, remains loyal to King Kumärpäl's legacy and dies fighting his unjust successor, King Ajaypäl.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The warrior Ämbad stands bravely against the troops of King Ajaypäl.

graphicsData.title: A Promise Fulfilled
graphicsData.description: Thanks to the dedication of Bähad and the contributions of many, Udayan's vow is fulfilled with the completion of the grand temple in 1157 A.D.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The magnificent, newly completed temple stands proudly on Shatrunjay hill.
